title: Shots Heard in Marais Neighborhood of Paris; Appears to Be False Alarm
content:
The sound of gunfire was reportedly heard Sunday afternoon along Rue de Rivoli in the Marais, a historic neighborhood in the Third and Fourth Arrondissements of Paris.  After frightening moments, in which pedestrians scattered, the episode appears to have been a false alarm.

https://twitter.com/emilielopez/status/665949982055399424

Witnesses reported that police officers in military-style gear were seen running through the neighborhood and residents were reportedly clearing out of the neighborhood or seeking shelter. 

https://twitter.com/cbtly/status/665947391107932160

https://twitter.com/mathieuvonrohr/status/665946435200933888

Liz Alderman, a New York Times correspondent reports that witnesses told her shots were heard at Place de la République, a main square in Paris, on Rue Bichat.  There were helicopters flying overhead and crowds of pedestrians who had gathered only two days after the deadly attacks in the French capital were startled.  

Ms. Alderman reports that people were seen running through the Marais seeking safety. All of the nearby cafes were suddenly shuttered, and diners hid inside restaurants and stores.

Lilia Blaise, a researcher for The New York Times in Paris, spoke to the owner of a bar in the neighborhood, Café Charlot, on Rue Bretagne.

"I did not hear anything but I saw everyone in the terrace getting up and rushing inside," he said. "We are closing the doors."

With a manhunt still going on, Parisians are obviously on edge and the city is operating with an abundance of caution.

Ms. Alderman reports that officers were shouting at people to get inside, and many people took shelter in nearby restaurants.

"How long is this going to go on?" asked Sarah Ginon, who was hiding in a restaurant on Rue Vieille du Temple. "This is the first day after the massacres that I decided to come out. Now I see that we should not have, it's not safe at all."

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
The sound of gunfire was reportedly heard Sunday afternoon along Rue de Rivoli in the Marais, a historic neighborhood in the Third and Fourth Arrondissements of Paris. After frightening moments, in which pedestrians scattered, the episode appears to have been a false alarm.

Le serveur nous dit qu'un flic lui a affirmé que ça a tiré des deux côtés. Un mec nous accueille chez lui spontanément. #marais

— Emilie Lopez (@emilielopez) November 15, 2015

Witnesses reported that police officers in military-style gear were seen running through the neighborhood and residents were reportedly clearing out of the neighborhood or seeking shelter.

Paris – Shots heard in Rue de Rivoli, Marais. Be safe everyone!

— Claire Barthelemy (@cbtly) November 15, 2015

Getting reports from the Marais. Unclear what's happening. Lots of police.

— Mathieu von Rohr (@mathieuvonrohr) November 15, 2015

Liz Alderman, a New York Times correspondent reports that witnesses told her shots were heard at Place de la République, a main square in Paris, on Rue Bichat. There were helicopters flying overhead and crowds of pedestrians who had gathered only two days after the deadly attacks in the French capital were startled.

Ms. Alderman reports that people were seen running through the Marais seeking safety. All of the nearby cafes were suddenly shuttered, and diners hid inside restaurants and stores.

Lilia Blaise, a researcher for The New York Times in Paris, spoke to the owner of a bar in the neighborhood, Café Charlot, on Rue Bretagne.

“I did not hear anything but I saw everyone in the terrace getting up and rushing inside,” he said. “We are closing the doors.”

With a manhunt still going on, Parisians are obviously on edge and the city is operating with an abundance of caution.

Ms. Alderman reports that officers were shouting at people to get inside, and many people took shelter in nearby restaurants.

“How long is this going to go on?” asked Sarah Ginon, who was hiding in a restaurant on Rue Vieille du Temple. “This is the first day after the massacres that I decided to come out. Now I see that we should not have, it’s not safe at all.”

title: French Authorities Publish Information About Wanted Suspect
content:
The French authorities published the name and photograph of a man wanted in the Paris attacks on Sunday, and appealed for the public's help in tracking him down. 

The man, Salah Abdeslam, was born on Sept. 15, 1989, in Brussels. The name and photo was posted on Twitter. The electronic wanted poster also described him as being 5 feet 7 inches and having brown eyes.   

The police said that Mr. Abdeslam had been "potentially involved" in the Friday attacks, but did not provide details as to what role he might have played.  

A warrant has been issued for his arrest. Even as they requested the public's help, the authorities warned that Mr. Abdeslam was a "dangerous individual" and that the public should not "intervene on your own under any circumstances."

https://twitter.com/PNationale/status/665939383418273793

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

The man, Salah Abdeslam, was born on Sept. 15, 1989, in Brussels. The name and photo was posted on Twitter. The electronic wanted poster also described him as being 5 feet 7 inches and having brown eyes.

The police said that Mr. Abdeslam had been “potentially involved” in the Friday attacks, but did not provide details as to what role he might have played.

A warrant has been issued for his arrest. Even as they requested the public’s help, the authorities warned that Mr. Abdeslam was a “dangerous individual” and that the public should not “intervene on your own under any circumstances.”

[AppelàTémoin] La #PJ recherche 1 individu susceptible d'être impliqué ds les attentats du 13/11/2015 #ParisAttacks pic.twitter.com/Gpr4MY1I53

— Police Nationale (@PNationale) November 15, 2015

title: France Identifies Two More Terrorist Suspects
content: The Paris prosecutor's office said in a statement on Sunday that "two new terrorists who died on the evening of Nov. 13 have been formally identified today after collection and comparison of their fingerprints." François Molins, the Paris prosecutor, said in the statement that one of the men was among the suicide bombers outside the Stade de France and that he was born in France on Jan. 22, 1995. The second attacker identified Sunday was the suicide bomber who killed himself, but no one else, in the Comptoir Voltaire restaurant. He was also born in France, on July 30, 1984. Both men lived in Belgium, according to Mr. Molins. He did not name the attackers in his statement and said that authorities are still trying to identify the other dead attackers. Four have been identified so far.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
The Paris prosecutor’s office said in a statement on Sunday that “two new terrorists who died on the evening of Nov. 13 have been formally identified today after collection and comparison of their fingerprints.”

François Molins, the Paris prosecutor, said in the statement that one of the men was among the suicide bombers outside the Stade de France and that he was born in France on Jan. 22, 1995.

The second attacker identified Sunday was the suicide bomber who killed himself, but no one else, in the Comptoir Voltaire restaurant. He was also born in France, on July 30, 1984.

Both men lived in Belgium, according to Mr. Molins. He did not name the attackers in his statement and said that authorities are still trying to identify the other dead attackers. Four have been identified so far.

title: A ‘Raw’ Reaction Becomes a Symbol of Solidarity
content:
Jean Jullien, a French illustrator based in London, heard about the attacks listening to French radio on Friday. In response, he drew a simple silhouette of the Eiffel Tower within the universal peace sign and shared it on Twitter, Instagram and Facebook.

https://twitter.com/jean_jullien/status/665305363500011521

Over the next 48 hours, the image became a symbol of solidarity with France worldwide. It now adorns improvised shrines at the crime scenes in Paris, and it is still being shared online by thousands around the world.

"I draw. That is my way of expressing myself," Mr. Jullien, 32, said in a phone interview. "The first thing I could come up with was a need for peace in reaction to this horrible violence. It was a very raw, spontaneous reaction. I didn’t sketch anything before."
 
That his work was widely credited to Bansky, the British artist, did not upset him.

"It wasn’t something that I did to benefit from," he said. "It was just a spontaneous reaction as a citizen, not as a professional. The credit didn’t matter.

“I have a lot friends, family and colleagues in Paris, and it is a city I love. I felt extremely worried for my close ones and for everyone, really."

[nytmedia id="100000004038746" crop="480" type="image"]

Mr Jullien, who has contributed to The New York Times, said he has received numerous requests from people wanting to "put the drawing on T-shirts and mugs." He has been telling them to do whatever they want as long as all profits go toward victims or their families.

"The more we can help with that simple drawing, the better," he said.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Jean Jullien, a French illustrator based in London, heard about the attacks listening to French radio on Friday. In response, he drew a simple silhouette of the Eiffel Tower within the universal peace sign and shared it on Twitter, Instagram and Facebook.

Peace for Paris pic.twitter.com/ryf6XB2d80

— jean jullien (@jean_jullien) November 13, 2015

Over the next 48 hours, the image became a symbol of solidarity with France worldwide. It now adorns improvised shrines at the crime scenes in Paris, and it is still being shared online by thousands around the world.

“I draw. That is my way of expressing myself,” Mr. Jullien, 32, said in a phone interview. “The first thing I could come up with was a need for peace in reaction to this horrible violence. It was a very raw, spontaneous reaction. I didn’t sketch anything before.”

That his work was widely credited to Bansky, the British artist, did not upset him.

“It wasn’t something that I did to benefit from,” he said. “It was just a spontaneous reaction as a citizen, not as a professional. The credit didn’t matter.

“I have a lot friends, family and colleagues in Paris, and it is a city I love. I felt extremely worried for my close ones and for everyone, really.”

Mr Jullien, who has contributed to The New York Times, said he has received numerous requests from people wanting to “put the drawing on T-shirts and mugs.” He has been telling them to do whatever they want as long as all profits go toward victims or their families.

“The more we can help with that simple drawing, the better,” he said.

title: A Belgian Community Haunted by Links to Terror
content: Revelations on Sunday that one of the terrorists involved in the Paris attacks and five people arrested in connection with the plot were from Molenbeek in Brussels were in keeping with a well-established pattern. The links to terrorism in Molenbeek are not new: Amedy Coulibaly, who shot and killed shoppers in a kosher supermarket in Paris in January, is believed to have bought weapons in Molenbeek. So did Mehdi Nemmouche, a Frenchman who targeted Jews at a Brussels museum in May 2014, killing four. Ayoub el Kahzani, a Moroccan who was thwarted in his attempt to attack passengers on a high-speed train traveling between Brussels and Paris in August is also thought to have lived there for a while. Molenbeek is one of the poorest areas of Brussels, with youth unemployment at about 40 percent and many young people feeling that they are discriminated against for jobs, said an aide to the mayor, Ann Gilles Goris. Molenbeek is known to be home to many French-speaking people from the Maghreb and the Middle East, and many young residents said in interview that they knew someone who had joined the conflict in Syria. Five people were arrested in Molenbeek  after the police swooped in on the area Saturday evening in a raid that lasted well into the night, according to federal prosecutors,. Molenbeek residents said they saw the police take young men away from their homes or haul them off the streets before driving them away in police vans. At least three of the arrests took place within a short distance of one another. According to Sheikh Rozina, the owner of a clothing shop, the police broke into an apartment overlooking a popular marketplace and took two brothers into custody. Ms. Rozina, whose shop is in the same building where the men were arrested, said the two were born in Brussels to Moroccan parents,  “were very nice, very polite” and greeted him every morning. They were about 25 and 26 years old, she said, and usually wore long, white traditional robes. One had a small beard while the other was clean-shaven, Ms. Rozina said. On Sunday, she said, “I saw the mother crying.”

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Revelations on Sunday that one of the terrorists involved in the Paris attacks and five people arrested in connection with the plot were from Molenbeek in Brussels were in keeping with a well-established pattern.

The links to terrorism in Molenbeek are not new: Amedy Coulibaly, who shot and killed shoppers in a kosher supermarket in Paris in January, is believed to have bought weapons in Molenbeek.

So did Mehdi Nemmouche, a Frenchman who targeted Jews at a Brussels museum in May 2014, killing four. Ayoub el Kahzani, a Moroccan who was thwarted in his attempt to attack passengers on a high-speed train traveling between Brussels and Paris in August is also thought to have lived there for a while.

Molenbeek is one of the poorest areas of Brussels, with youth unemployment at about 40 percent and many young people feeling that they are discriminated against for jobs, said an aide to the mayor, Ann Gilles Goris.

Molenbeek is known to be home to many French-speaking people from the Maghreb and the Middle East, and many young residents said in interview that they knew someone who had joined the conflict in Syria.

Five people were arrested in Molenbeek  after the police swooped in on the area Saturday evening in a raid that lasted well into the night, according to federal prosecutors,.

Molenbeek residents said they saw the police take young men away from their homes or haul them off the streets before driving them away in police vans. At least three of the arrests took place within a short distance of one another.

According to Sheikh Rozina, the owner of a clothing shop, the police broke into an apartment overlooking a popular marketplace and took two brothers into custody.

Ms. Rozina, whose shop is in the same building where the men were arrested, said the two were born in Brussels to Moroccan parents,  “were very nice, very polite” and greeted him every morning.

They were about 25 and 26 years old, she said, and usually wore long, white traditional robes. One had a small beard while the other was clean-shaven, Ms. Rozina said. On Sunday, she said, “I saw the mother crying.”

title: U.S. Defense Secretary Coordinating With France
content:
Ashton B. Carter, the United States secretary of defense, spoke to his counterpart in France about collaboration between the two nations in fighting the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. The Pentagon provided a statement:
Secretary of Defense Ash Carter and French Minister of Defense Jean-Yves Le Drian spoke again by phone this morning – their second call since the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday night. This was an opportunity to share actions that both governments are taking in the wake of the attack. They agreed on concrete steps the U.S. and French militaries should take to further intensify our close cooperation in prosecuting a sustained campaign against ISIL. Secretary Carter reiterated the firm commitment of the United States to support France and move together to ensure ISIL is dealt a lasting defeat. They agreed to continue to remain in close contact in the days ahead.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Ashton B. Carter, the United States secretary of defense, spoke to his counterpart in France about collaboration between the two nations in fighting the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. The Pentagon provided a statement:

Secretary of Defense Ash Carter and French Minister of Defense Jean-Yves Le Drian spoke again by phone this morning – their second call since the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday night. This was an opportunity to share actions that both governments are taking in the wake of the attack. They agreed on concrete steps the U.S. and French militaries should take to further intensify our close cooperation in prosecuting a sustained campaign against ISIL. Secretary Carter reiterated the firm commitment of the United States to support France and move together to ensure ISIL is dealt a lasting defeat. They agreed to continue to remain in close contact in the days ahead.

title: Belgium Calls for Tighter European Borders
content:
Jan Jambon, the Belgian minister of security and home affairs, speaking to reporters on Sunday, said his country was in favor of stricter border controls in Europe as he expressed support for France in the wake of the Paris attacks. 

Belgium and France “completely agree and are on the same wavelength in this regard,” Mr. Jambon said. 

“It is quite right to say that we talk a lot but we don’t implement the measures in the field,” he said. “I am sure that we can make things change more quickly.”

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Jan Jambon, the Belgian minister of security and home affairs, speaking to reporters on Sunday, said his country was in favor of stricter border controls in Europe as he expressed support for France in the wake of the Paris attacks.

Belgium and France “completely agree and are on the same wavelength in this regard,” Mr. Jambon said.

“It is quite right to say that we talk a lot but we don’t implement the measures in the field,” he said. “I am sure that we can make things change more quickly.”

title: Events Draw Both Inspiration and Misinformation on Social Media
content: As the worst terrorist attack in French history unfolded on Friday, the world showed its support on social media. Parisians offered their homes to strangers who needed refuge, using the hashtag #PorteOuverte, which means "open door." Others, trying to find their loved ones, scanned tweets tagged #ParisRecherche. But social media also has a dark side, giving rise to rumors and false information. In Britain, soccer fans thought they had seen Martin Kelly, a defender for Crystal Palace, in a photo taken in front of the Bataclan. Mr. Kelly, safe in Paris, debunked the rumors. https://twitter.com/MartinKelly1990/status/665641651889680384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw An illustration of the Eiffel Tower inside a peace sign became a popular image of support. https://twitter.com/jean_jullien/status/665305363500011521?lang=en The work was often credited to the British artist Banksy, but it was actually made by Jean Jullien, an artist who has contributed to The New York Times. A photo of jubilant fans at an Eagles of Death Metal concert was circulated by some users who said it had been taken at the Bataclan on Friday, minutes before attackers opened fire. A tweet from earlier this month by the band that included the photo, however, showed that the show was in Dublin, not Paris. https://twitter.com/EODMofficial/status/664590847384514560?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw As investigations continued, Veerender Jubbal, a journalist, discovered a photo of himself wearing a suicide vest and holding a copy of the Quran. A Twitter account called Grasswire Fact Check found that the photo had been doctored, and pointed to the original photo Mr. Jubbal posted in August: https://twitter.com/Veeren_Jubbal/status/628669930704015360/photo/1

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
As the worst terrorist attack in French history unfolded on Friday, the world showed its support on social media. Parisians offered their homes to strangers who needed refuge, using the hashtag #PorteOuverte, which means “open door.” Others, trying to find their loved ones, scanned tweets tagged #ParisRecherche.

But social media also has a dark side, giving rise to rumors and false information.

In Britain, soccer fans thought they had seen Martin Kelly, a defender for Crystal Palace, in a photo taken in front of the Bataclan. Mr. Kelly, safe in Paris, debunked the rumors.

I've seen pictures of a guy who looks like me helping the victims, just to clarify this wasn't me.

— Martin Kelly (@MartinKelly1990) November 14, 2015

An illustration of the Eiffel Tower inside a peace sign became a popular image of support.

Peace for Paris pic.twitter.com/ryf6XB2d80

— jean jullien (@jean_jullien) November 13, 2015

The work was often credited to the British artist Banksy, but it was actually made by Jean Jullien, an artist who has contributed to The New York Times.

A photo of jubilant fans at an Eagles of Death Metal concert was circulated by some users who said it had been taken at the Bataclan on Friday, minutes before attackers opened fire. A tweet from earlier this month by the band that included the photo, however, showed that the show was in Dublin, not Paris.

This view never, ever, ever gets old. Taken last night at @olympiatheatre from behind @juliandorio's kit. #Dublin pic.twitter.com/ZdUNDwCgf4

— EaglesOfDeathMetal (@EODMofficial) November 11, 2015

As investigations continued, Veerender Jubbal, a journalist, discovered a photo of himself wearing a suicide vest and holding a copy of the Quran. A Twitter account called Grasswire Fact Check found that the photo had been doctored, and pointed to the original photo Mr. Jubbal posted in August:

Ready: pic.twitter.com/ae9xEej4gS

— Veerender Jubbal (@Veeren_Jubbal) August 4, 2015

title: A Day Before France, Attacks Struck Lebanon
content:
Paris has received a global outpouring of sympathy in the past few days. 

Many in Lebanon, which was struck by a double suicide bombing last week, note that they did not get the same attention.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/16/world/middleeast/beirut-lebanon-attacks-paris.html

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

content_expanded:
Paris has received a global outpouring of sympathy in the past few days.

Many in Lebanon, which was struck by a double suicide bombing last week, note that they did not get the same attention.

Beirut, Also the Site of Deadly Attacks, Feels Forgotten

By ANNE BARNARD

A global outpouring of grief followed the Paris assaults, but no such solidarity was expressed a day earlier when 43 civilians were killed in Lebanon.

title: Fire Destroys Planned Asylum Shelter in Germany
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004038704" crop="592" type="image"]

A fire broke out overnight at a planned asylum shelter on the Baltic Sea island of Usedom, making it unusable, the police said on Sunday.

It was the first such incident reported in Germany since the Paris attacks. There have been 500 or more attacks on shelters for refugees in Germany this year, scores of them arson, but the police said that the cause of the overnight blaze, in the village of Trassenheide, was unclear.

The building had been a two-story office for a construction firm; it had been converted into four apartments, where 15 refugees were supposed to move in on Thursday, police officers in the Neubrandenburg region of eastern Germany said. It took 48 firefighters to bring the fire under control after it was reported, shortly after 3 a.m. Sunday.

parent.title: Attacks in Paris: Live Updates From France

It was the first such incident reported in Germany since the Paris attacks. There have been 500 or more attacks on shelters for refugees in Germany this year, scores of them arson, but the police said that the cause of the overnight blaze, in the village of Trassenheide, was unclear.

The building had been a two-story office for a construction firm; it had been converted into four apartments, where 15 refugees were supposed to move in on Thursday, police officers in the Neubrandenburg region of eastern Germany said. It took 48 firefighters to bring the fire under control after it was reported, shortly after 3 a.m. Sunday.
